Holiday TV calendar: A little something for everyone

USA Today 9:07 a.m. EST November 30, 2014

Frosty and his friend set off on a whirlwind adventure in the classic holiday special 'Frosty the Snowman' airing Friday.(Photo: CBS)

477 CONNECT 8 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Need to get into the holiday spirit? Here is a selection of seasonal television specials on the networks' lineups:

FROSTY THE SNOWMAN (CBS, FRIDAY, 9 ET/PT): Frosty must high-tail it back to the North Pole before he's a corn cob pipe and a button nose floating in a pool of water. (You know, you could also could try Buffalo, Frosty.)

PREP AND LANDING (ABC, Friday, 8 PM ET): When the president of the United States travels, he has the Secret Service advance team; Santa has Prep and Landing. (Followed by its 2011 sequel Naughty Vs. Nice at 8:30.)

GRANDMA GOT RUN OVER BY A REINDEER (CW, Friday, 8 ET/PT): The novelty song about losing the family matriarch on Christmas Eve comes to life in this animated movie. (Maybe the movie will answer this burning question: Did they open up her gifts or send them back?)

KUNG FU PANDA HOLIDAY (CW, Friday, 9:00 ET/PT): After being put in charge of the Winter Feast, Po (Jack Black) struggles to get all the cooking done. (As moms everywhere say, "I do that every year! Where's my holiday special?")

MERRY MADAGASCAR (CW, Friday, 9:30 ET): When King Julien shoots down Santa's sleigh, Alex (Ben Stiller) and his friends decide to deliver all of St. Nick's gifts and use the sleigh to return home to New York.

THE STORY OF SANTA CLAUS (CBS, Saturday, 9 ET/PT): Santa gets his own origin story. Featuring the voices of Ed Asner and Betty White.

CMA COUNTRY CHRISTMAS (ABC, Dec. 1, Monday 8 ET/PT): The biggest stars in country music are aligning for a celebration of the holiday season, hosted by Jennifer Nettles. Artists scheduled to already officially performing during the two-hour specialinclude Dan + Shay, Brett Eldredge, Sara Evans, Lucy Hale, Hunter Hayes, Little Big Town, Idina Menzel, Jennifer Nettles, LeAnn Rimes, Michael W. Smith, and Carrie Underwood, but there will no doubt be more than a few surprises on this night full of country stars and Christmas cheer.

TOY STORY THAT TIME FORGOT (ABC, Dec. 2, 8 ET/PT): The latest from Pixar brings back all your favorite characters from theToy Story franchise as the whole gang find themselves in a sticky situation when a set of newfangled, not-so-nice action figures takes charge. Will the toys ever make it back to Bonnie's room?

A CHARLIE BROWN CHRISTMAS (ABC, Dec. 2, 8:30 ET/PT) This one's a classic for many reasons. Chief among them: Charlie Brown's commentary on the overcommercialization of Christmas. Plus, the soundtrack is one of the few holiday albums retail workers don't tire of hearing by Dec. 25. (And that's saying something.)

CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER (NBC, Dec. 3, Wednesday 8 ET/PT): A tradition as storied as the holiday itself is the annual lighting of the Christmas tree at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. This year's "Christmas in Rockefeller Center" special is hosted byToday show anchors Matt Lauer, Savannah Guthrie, Al Roker and Natalie Morales and features musical performances from Lady Gaga and Tony Bennett, Cyndi Lauper, Sara Bareilles, Idina Menzel, LeAnn Rimes, Pentatonix and Trisha Yearwoodperforming your favorite Christmas and holiday classics.

THE YEAR WITHOUT A SANTA CLAUS (ABC Family, Dec. 4, 6 p.m. ET/PT): When Santa calls in sick on Christmas Eve and the elves must handle his deliveries, things go awry.

HOW MURRAY SAVED CHRISTMAS (NBC, Dec. 5, Friday 8 ET/PT): A new animated special , "How Murray Saved Christmas" is a heartwarming and funny musical based on the best-selling children's book of the same name. When Santa (Kevin Michael Richardson) can't deliver the toys one Christmas, cranky deli owner Murray Weiner (Jerry Stiller) is forced to fill in with the help of Edison Elf (Sean Hayes). The results are certainly not what you'd expect

A VERY GRAMMY CHRISTMAS (CBS, Dec. 5, Friday 9 ET/PT): This new special for 2014 features musical performances fromsome of the biggest names in music today, including Ariana Grande, Maroon 5, Tim McGraw and Pharrell Williams. In addition to the full slate of fantastic performances, the Nominees for the Grammy Award for album of the year will be announced live during the special. – so don't miss out!

THE LITTLE DRUMMER BOY (ABC Family, Dec. 7, 9 a.m. ET/PT): A misanthropic orphan's life is changed when he crosses paths with the Three Wise Men and a certain infant in a manger.

RUDOLPH THE RED-NOSED REINDEER (CBS, Dec. 9, 8 ET/PT): Shunned for his glowing schnoz, Rudolph finds kindred souls on the Island of Misfit Toys, especially Hermey the Elf, the wannabe dentist. Soon, both their special skills save the day.

I LOVE LUCY CHRISTMAS SPECIAL (CBS, Dec. 7, 8 ET/PT): CBS combines two of the classic sitcom's best-loved holiday outings, including the oh-so-creatively named "Christmas Episode" and "Job Switching," better known as "Chocolate Factory," where Lucy and Ethel try to keep pace with an assembly line of sweets.

SANTA CLAUS IS COMIN' TO TOWN (ABC, Dec. 9, 8 ET/PT): Kris Kringle tries to deliver gifts to Sombertown, where toys are forbidden by the cranky-pants mayor. Talk about no good deed goes unpunished. (Repeats Dec. 21 on ABC Family at 1 p.m. ET.)

FROSTY RETURNS (CBS, Dec. 13, 9:30 ET/PT): The invention of "Summer Wheeze," an aerosol spray that evaporates snow, puts Frosty's survival at risk again.

ELF: BUDDY'S MUSICAL CHRISTMAS (NBC, Dec. 16, Tuesday 8 ET/PT): This new stop-motion, musical Christmas specialhas Big Bang Theory star Jim Parsons steps ping into Will Ferrell's iconic green elf suit in this new stop-motion musicalChristmas special as , providing the voice for everyone's favorite elf, Buddy. In this newest take on Buddy's hilarious story, Santa himself narrates Buddy's travels to the Big Apple to meet his father and bring joy to everyone he meets through the power of Christmas cheer. Because after all, "the best way to spread Christmas cheer is singing loud for all to hear!"

MICHAEL BUBLE'S CHRISTMAS IN NEW YORK (NBC, Dec. 17, Wednesday 8 ET/PT): The fourth annual special features Barbra Streisand, Ariana Grande, Miss Piggy and the Rockettes. year,running Michael Buble is taking over NBC to produce his own holiday variety show, ","Michael Buble's Christmas in New Yorkfrom the legendary Radio City Music Hall. His guest stars haven't been announced, but knowing Buble, they're sure to be fun for the whole family.

THE iHEARTRADIO JINGLE BALL 2014 (CW, Dec. 18, Thursday 8 ET/PT): Musical performers include all of today's biggest hit-makers including Taylor Swift, Iggy Azalea, Maroon 5, Ariana Grande, Sam Smith, Meghan Trainor, Pharrell Williams, 5 Seconds of Summer, Jessie J and OneRepublic performing live at the legendary Madison Square Garden in New York City.

MR. MAGOO'S CHRISTMAS CAROL (CW, Dec. 19, 8 ET/PT): This 1962 retelling of Charles Dickens' A Christmas Carol holds the distinction of being the first animated holiday special made for TV.

I WANT A DOG FOR CHRISTMAS, CHARLIE BROWN! (ABC, Dec. 20, 8 ET/PT): When Linus and Lucy's little brother, Rerun, declares he would like a dog of his own, Charlie Brown lets him do a trial run with Snoopy to prove he can handle the responsibility.

ONE DIRECTION: THE TV SPECIAL (NBC, Dec. 23, Tuesday 8 ET/PT): If you thought you were going to spend quality family time with your teenage daughter this holiday, think again. British boy band sensation One Direction headlines its have announced their first ever TV special. will air on December 23We don't have a lot of details yet, but we can only hope the boys bring back the old-school-style holiday special that everyone can enjoy.

SHREK THE HALLS (ABC. Dec. 23, 8 ET/PT): As Shrek consults Christmas for Village Idiots to learn how to throw a proper holiday celebration for Fiona, Donkey and the rest of his friends share Christmas stories.

DR SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS (ABC, Dec. 25, 8:30 ET/PT): The cave-dwelling curmudgeon with a heart two sizes two small fails to stop Christmas from coming to Whoville, despite stealing all their presents and decorations. The animated classic (8 ET/PT) precedes the live-action feature film from 2000 starring Jim Carrey.
